newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanese arrive in Beirut from Sierra Leone.
newsitem.headline: Lebanese arrive in Beirut from Sierra Leone.

text.p: A Middle East Airlines jet carrying 240 Lebanese nationals evacuated from Sierra Leone after a weekend military coup arrived in Beirut on Thursday.
Most of the passengers were women and children. The craft also carried the bodies of two Lebanese men killed by gunmen in the chaos on Sunday.
Billionaire businessman Jamil Saeed, who arrived on board the airliner that also carried the body of his 27-year-old son, fell to the ground after getting off the craft.
One woman said every Lebanese family was forced to pay the armed forces in Sierra Leone $2,000.
"Our shops, possessions and cars have been looted and all Lebanese shops have been emptied of all kinds of goods," the woman, who wished not to be identified, told reporters at the airport.
Many of the 2,000 Lebanese living in Sierra Leone, most of them businessmen, took shelter at the Lebanese embassy in Freetown, where they suffered shortages of food and water.
A woman who refused to be identified said that the status of some 500 Lebanese nationals living outside Freetown was unknown.
The coup, led by Major Johnny Paul Koromah, overthrew the elected government of President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah.
The evacuation of foreigners has taken on added urgency because of moves by Nigeria, backbone of a regional peacekeeping force, to reverse Sunday's coup.
Britain planned to begin evacuating its citizens and other Westeners from Sierra Leone on Thursday.
Mohamad Aziz, head of operations at Middle East Airlines, said negotiations were under way to send other airliners to evacuate more Lebanese.
"If security is guaranteed, we will send another plane in 24 hours," Aziz said.
